text: I can still be a part of a vigorous
national debate without having to offer
myself for the presidency you have to
believe as I've said before it in your
heart and in your mind that you're ready
and I don't believe that I am I did not
run for this job for failure I ran for
this job for success for success not
just for me personally in my children
but success for my state and hopefully
to provide an example for the rest of
the country that you can do the
difficult things New Jersey Governor
Chris Christie has made a national name
for himself with his blunt style and
aggressive approach to budget cutting
and labor unions and despite his promise
not to run on the Republican ticket in
2012 he is sure to play a role in
shaping his party's politics Governor
Christie thank you for being here with
the caucus at New York Times let's start
with collective bargaining that's
obviously in the news what would be
gained by denying public workers the
right to collectively bargain the
problem in New Jersey is we've had
collective bargain that's been one-sided
cut the bargaining you know where no
one's been in there stay enough for the
taxpayer and vigorously bargaining in an
adversarial nature that's the nature of
collective bargaining it's an
adversarial situation which you hope
ultimately leads to a to a collective
decision the problem here is that the
unions want to have it both ways they
want collective bargaining but then if
they don't get everything they wanted to
cut the bargaining table they use their
money to go to the legislature and get
enhanced benefits and then when we try
to take some of those enhanced benefits
back legislatively say oh you're
violating the sanctity of the collective
bargaining process well listen you can't
have it both ways you've been pretty
blunt about your assessment of President
Obama as leadership as a leader in his
leadership role you've you've
practically called him a coward for not
legal remember my critique of President
Obama was specifically on one thing
which was on the social security
medicare medicaid troika that he refused
to deal with in the context of his state
of the union or his budget that he put
forward in other ways i think the
president has been very courageous in
some of his leadership on education
reform I think he's been very courageous
especially for a Democrat I thought his
leadership in the aftermath of the
Arizona
shooting was something that was real
good leadership and brought the country
together in some areas of renewable
energy i agree with the president I
don't want it to be mischaracterized
that I've said he's not a good leader
what I've said was he disappointed me
when he didn't step up and deal with the
thing that consumes 80-plus percent of
the federal budget which are those three
huge entitlement programs because it is
the defining financial issue of our time
stay with that subject but shift to the
2012 presidential campaign do you see
that issue the entitlement issue as also
defining that race and what how do you
and how do you think people should sort
out you know the candidates that are
going to come forward on the Republican
side to challenge the president well
it's hard to tell given that it's a good
year off I think it should be because I
think anybody who wants for president is
unwilling to talk about entitlements and
put forward their plan on how they deal
with it is selling people short and so
how it will shake out in the Republican
primary I think it's very dependent upon
who it is is there anybody that you see
that you have confidence in at this
early stage that will talk about that
well I think this I think governor
Daniels gave a very thoughtful speech on
that at CPAC a week or so ago and he
talked about that in some some real
detail and I think governor Daniels you
know has credibility given some of the
things he's done as a budget balancer in
Indiana let me read you a couple of
quotes one quote leadership today in
America has to be about doing the big
things and being courageous now is the
time it matters most in New Jersey's
future and America's future and then
finally I started the conversation I
took the risk I think that's what we
elect leaders for hence the name you
know all of which suggests an impatience
and a desire for leaders to step up and
yet you're you've said you're not going
to step up and run for president why
should people not think that you're
preaching something to others that
you're not following yourself well
listen what I'm trying to do is inspire
a conversation among those people who
but want to be probably not start the
country so why not be part of the
conversation in the next year well
because I think that's an intensely
personal decision I mean it doesn't mean
you can't have opinions on what the
Nationals you should be
just because you're not willing to run
for president yourself and I think
that's a false choice I can still be a
part of a vigorous national debate and
weigh in on my views on those things
without having to offer myself for the
presidency and I think that's such a
personal decision you have to believe as
I've said before it in your heart and in
your mind that you're ready and I don't
believe that I am you're a big guy
people talk about that all the time do
you sense that your physical bigness is
a political asset it depends on the day
it depends on that day you know I mean
some days I think you know people New
Jersey look at me and say yeah you know
he struggles with his weight and so do i
and it probably makes them feel that
maybe I understand them a little bit
more because I've so my own personal
struggles you know other days just look
at my twitter page you know and see some
of the awful things that are written
about the fact that I've struggles with
my weight some of the terrible things
that people say in the end of it you
know I need to get another control so I
can have my long-term health and I've
you know for kids between 7 and 17 I
want to be around to watch them get
married and have children themselves
you
